Heteroleptic dirhodium(II,II) acetato-bipyridyl complexes: Evaluation as catalyst precursors for hydroformylation reactions Stephen de Doncker Investigation Writing – original draft Data curation Validation Gregory S. Smith Conceptualization Funding acquisition Writing – review & editing Resources ⁎ Siyabonga Ngubane Conceptualization Funding acquisition Resources Writing – review & editing Supervision ⁎ Department of Chemistry, University of Cape Town, Rondebosch, 7701, South Africa Department of Chemistry, University of Cape Town Rondebosch 7701 South Africa Department of Chemistry, University of Cape Town, Rondebosch, 7701, South Africa ⁎ Corresponding authors. The synthesis of cationic bimetallic ‘pseudo-paddlewheel’ dirhodium(II,II) acetato-bipyridyl complexes of the type [Rh2(OAc)2(bis-4,4′-R-bipy)2]2+ containing either acetate (AcO-) or hexafluorophosphate (PF 6 - ) counter ions is described. In both series, the 4 and 4′ positions of each bipyridyl ligand are substituted such that R = H, CF3 or OMe (complexes 1-3 for AcO- and 4-6 for PF6 - derivatives). As catalyst precursors for the hydroformylation reaction, the complexes were initially evaluated using 1-octene as a substrate. The complex which displayed the greatest chemoselectivity toward aldehydes was evaluated further as a catalyst precursor for the hydroformylation of styrene, cyclohexene and 7-tetradecene as substrates. A correlation between product distributions in terms of chemo- and regioselectivity in the hydroformylation reaction versus axial site interaction is delineated. Recyclability was achieved through suitable modification of the substituent and counter ion, culminating in a simplistic method of post-catalytic precursor collection with minimal reduction of the catalytic activity over 5 cycles. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords Hydroformylation Dirhodium(II,II) Homogeneous Recyclability Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction The use of transition metal complexes as catalysts is an ongoing and growing area of research, due to efficient and targeted production of value-added chemicals from industrially relevant low-value feedstocks [1–3]. Catalytic processes offer alternatives to the use of harmful reagents, by-product formation and the production of waste commonly associated with stoichiometric reactions by providing alternative lower energy pathways to obtain products, often resulting in increased selectivity of the reaction [4–6]. Transition metal catalysis research is at the forefront of industrially relevant reactions, providing insight into both heterogeneous and homogeneous facets of catalysis [7–11]. In terms of homogeneous catalysis, hydroformylation is one of the largest industrially relevant reactions, producing a substantial amount of value-added aldehydes each year from lower-value alkene feedstocks ( Scheme 1) [12,13]. Products of the hydroformylation process account for a large proportion of precursor material for chemical synthesis as well as the agrichemical and pharmaceutical sectors, and are necessary components in the production of flavor, fragrances and surfactants through known tandem catalytic reactions [14–17]. The use of rhodium-based catalyst precursors results in enhanced activity in the hydroformylation reaction under milder conditions when appropriate ligand modifications are carried out, compared to other metal-based counterparts [18,19]. A major drawback of a homogeneous catalytic system is recyclability, where separation and recovery of the catalyst precursor from the reaction mixture is usually an energy intensive process [20]. Owing to the rising cost of precious metals used in the synthesis of efficient catalyst precursors, the design of an ideal catalytic system should therefore consist of a catalyst precursor capable of the high activity characteristic of a homogeneous system, coupled with the excellent recyclability aspect of a heterogeneous system [21–23]. Therefore, research focus into improving catalyst recovery while maintaining the high activity and selectivity of homogenous catalyst systems is widely reported, such as immobilization of the catalyst precursor via insoluble supports or incorporation into macromolecular frameworks [24,25]. Additionally, cyclodextrin-inclusion complexes, fluorous or aqueous biphasic systems, as well as ionic liquid-based strategies are examples of further efforts toward catalyst recyclability being explored [26–32]. Further tuning of selected physicochemical properties such as solubility may be advantageous for enhanced catalyst recovery in hydroformylation due to the thermal requirements of the reactions, whereby temperature dependent solute-solvent interactions are exploited such as is the case in fluorous-biphasic catalysis [32]. Since their inception, dirhodium(II,II) complexes containing a metal-metal bond have been reported as catalyst precursors for a variety of reactions such as cycloaddition, hydrogen liberation, CO2 reduction, benzylic oxidation and diamination due to the extension of electronic and physicochemical properties imparted by the bimetallic, metal-metal bonded core [33–38]. As reported for mono-metallic complexes, the enhancement of activity and reactivity is often achieved through ligand modification by either varying substituents, aromaticity or ligand donor atom type [39–41]. A unique feature of dirhodium(II,II) complexes is the vacancy on the axial sites of the metal, available for ancillary ligand binding and thus offering further electronic tuning through interaction of suitably structured ligands or functionalizing a bridging ligand with an appropriate tether [42,43]. Structural modifications in such instances have shown significant effects on the product distributions of catalytic reactions such as cyclopropanation amongst others [44]. Furthermore, catalyst systems centered around mono-metallic rhodium-based complexes containing chelate ligands with either N,O- or N,P- and N,N’- donor atoms are reported to have significant influence on product distributions ( Fig. 1) [27,45–48]. Comparable modification to dirhodium(II,II) complexes have been undertaken through the use of N,N’-chelate ligands such as 2,2′-bipyridine, with reports on the combinations of bridging acetate and N,N′-chelate ligands showing enhancement of the physicochemical properties suitable to their applications [49,50]. In our previous study on the catalytic activity of homoleptic dirhodium(II,II) complexes, we remarked on the high chemoselectivity toward aldehyde production for complexes bearing bridging acetate ligands [51]. In the same report, the rhodium-fluorine axial site interaction observed for the complex containing bis(2-fluorophenyl)formamidinate ligands displayed the highest selectivity toward linear aldehyde, suggesting strong a influence of the axial site interactions on the regioselectivity in the hydroformylation reaction [51]. To the best of our knowledge, substituent variation of the ancillary bipyridyl ligands in heteroleptic dirhodium(II,II) acetato-bipyridyl complexes and the counter ion effects in homogeneous catalytic reactions remains unexplored, particularly for the hydroformylation reaction. Furthermore, the recyclability of dirhodium(II,II) complexes as catalyst precursors in catalytic reactions has not been reported without some attempt at immobilization of the catalyst [52]. Herein we report the synthesis, characterization and application of a series of dirhodium(II,II) acetato-bipyridyl complexes containing acetate and hexafluorophosphate counter ions as catalyst precursors in the hydroformylation of 1-octene, styrene, cyclohexene and 7-tetradecene, with development toward a means of post-catalytic recycling of the catalyst precursor. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials All chemicals/reagents were purchased from Merck and used without purification unless stated otherwise. Rhodium(III) trichloride trihydrate was purchased from Heraeus SA. Solvents of analytical grade were used as received or freshly distilled, where necessary, and were stored over molecular sieves. All reactions were carried out under Ar or N2 inert conditions, using standard Schlenk line techniques. Dirhodium(II,II) tetraacetate was synthesized as reported [51]. 2.2 Equipment and instrumentation Nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) spectra were recorded on either a Bruker X600 MHz spectrometer (1H at 599.95 MHz and 13C{1H} at 151.0 MHz), a Bruker X400 (1H: 400.22 MHz, 13C{1H}: 100.65 MHz, 19F: 377 MHz, 31P{1H}: 162 MHz) or a Varian Mercury 300 (1H: 300.08 MHz, 13C{1H}:75.46 MHz) spectrometer. Chemical shifts for 1H and 13C{1H} NMR were recorded using tetramethylsilane (TMS) as the internal standard. Coupling constants are reported in Hz and chemical shifts are reported in ppm relative to residual solvent signals. Infrared (IR) absorptions were recorded on a Perkin-Elmer Spectrum 100 FT-IR spectrometer using an Attenuated Total Reflectance Infrared spectroscopy (ATR-IR) attachment. High resolution mass spectrometry (HRMS) was carried out using Electron Impact (EI) on a JEOL GCmatell instrument with data recorded in positive mode. Melting Points were determined using a Büchi B-540 melting point apparatus, reported without correction. Purity of the complexes was determined using an Agilent HPLC 1260 equipped with an Agilent 1260 UV/Vis diode array detector (DAD) and an Agilent Pursuit 5 C18 column (5 μM, 150 mm × 4.6 mm). The compounds were eluted using a mixture of solvent A (0.1 % TFA in H2O) and solvent B (MeOH) at a flow rate of 0.5 mL/min. The gradient elution conditions were as follows: 90 % solvent A between 0 and 2 min, 90 – 10 % solvent A from 2 to 8 min, 10 % solvent A from 8 to 20 min. Conductivity measurements were carried out on a Jenway benchtop 4510 conductivity meter with a glass probe (κ = 0.96). Analysis of the hydroformylation samples of reactions were carried out on a Perkin Elmer Clarus 580 GC equipped with a flame-ionization detector (FID). The products were confirmed in relation to authentic standards for the hydroformylation products of 1-octene (internal-octenes and isomers of nonanal), styrene, cyclohexene and 7-tetradecene. 2.3 General method for the synthesis of dirhodium(II,II) acetato-bipyridyl diacetate complexes (1–3) The synthesis of dirhodium(II,II) complexes containing acetate counter ions was achieved through adaptation of the procedure reported for obtaining the known complex 1 [50]. A reaction vessel equipped with a stirrer bar was charged with dirhodium(II,II) tetraacetate (1 eq.) followed by anhydrous acetonitrile (10 mL). The mixture was stirred for up to 20 min until full dissolution was achieved. The required bis-4,4′-disubstituted 2,2′-bipyridyl ligand was added to the stirring solution (2 eq.) followed by an additional aliquot of anhydrous acetonitrile (5 mL). The reaction vessel was heated to reflux under N2 atmosphere and stirred for an additional 24 h, after which an observed color change from purple to brown-red was noted. The mixture was cooled to ambient temperature, before cooling in an ice bath for 1 h, resulting in the formation of a red precipitate, which was separated from the filtrate via suction filtration, washed with diethyl ether (3 ×10 mL) and dried in vacuo resulting in the isolation of a red-orange powder. 2.3.1 Dirhodium (II,II) bis-κ-(4,4′-(trifluoromethyl)− 2,2′-bipyridyl)-µ-bis-(di-acetato) diacetate (2) Dirhodium(II,II) tetraacetate (98 mg, 0.23 mmol) was reacted with 4,4′-bis(trifluoromethyl)− 2,2′-bipyridyl (0.13 g, 0.46 mmol) in anhydrous acetonitrile (15 mL) under reflux and N2 atmosphere for 24 h. All experiments were carried out in anhydrous acetonitrile containing a solution of 0.10 M tetra-n-butylammonium hexafluorophosphate (TBAPF6) as the supporting electrolyte. The C-3 cell stand equipped with a glassy carbon working electrode, Ag/AgNO3 (0.01 M TBAPF6/acetonitrile) reference electrode and a Pt wire auxiliary electrode was used to carry out electrochemical measurements. 2.6 General method for hydroformylation reactions Hydroformylation reactions were carried out in stainless steel pipe reactors (90 mL) equipped with a Teflon-coated magnetic stirrer bar. Each reactor was charged with toluene (5 mL), substrate (7.2 mmol), internal standard n-decane (1.26 mmol) and catalytic precursor (2.87 ×10−3 mmol), calculated per dirhodium core unit, equivalent to a rhodium metal loading of 5.74 × 10−3 mmol. The pipe reactor was purged with nitrogen three times, followed by purging with syngas (1:1, CO:H2) three times. The reactor was pressurized to the required pressure, followed by heating to the required temperature. Samples were collected at the beginning and end of each reaction. All reactions were performed in triplicate and are recorded as an average of three identical experiments. 2.7 Mercury poisoning study Mercury poisoning experiments were carried out in a 90 mL stainless steel pipe reactor charged with toluene (5 mL), 1-octene (7.2 mmol), internal standard n-decane (1.26 mmol) and catalytic precursor (complex 1) (2.87 ×10−3 mmol). To each reactor was added one drop of mercury, after which the reactors were sealed. The reactors were purged with N2 three times followed by purging with syngas three times, followed by pressurization to 40 bar and heating to 85 °C for 4 h. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Synthesis and characterization of dirhodium(II,II) acetato-bipyridyl diacetate (1–3) and bis-hexafluorophosphate (4-6) complexes The synthetic procedure for obtaining the target heteroleptic dirhodium (II,II) complexes was carried out by following a modified literature procedure ( Scheme 2) [51]. Variation of the bipyridyl substituents at the 4 and 4′ positions (H, OMe and CF3) was selected to determine whether any substantial electronic effects could be correlated to the observed product distribution in the hydroformylation reaction. The known diacetate complex 1 and new complexes 2 and 3 were isolated in moderate to good yields (79–96 %) as red powders. The 1H NMR spectra (Figs. S1-S3) confirm successful formation of the complexes with characteristic distinction between bridging and counter ion acetate signals integrating for 6 protons each and resonating in the 2.4 – 2.6 ppm and 1.7 – 1.9 ppm regions respectively. Signals corresponding to the bipyridyl protons for complexes 2 and 3 are observed as either doublets and/or singlets, as expected for protons in a 4,4′-disubstituted heteroaromatic bicyclic structural motif. The correct integration of these signals relative to the singlet corresponding to the bridging acetate protons, resonating in the 2.5 ppm region is observed. A notable downfield shift in the most deshielded bipyridyl doublet proton signal is observed (ca. 0.4 ppm) upon formation of the complexes relative to the obtained spectra of the bipyridyl ligand precursors. Further significant downfield shifts of the bipyridyl and bridging acetate signals are observed in the spectrum of complex 2 relative to complex 1. The latter presents as a shift from 2.56 to 2.60 ppm, due to the inductive withdrawing effect of the trifluoromethyl substituent. Although some interplay between inductive withdrawal and mesomeric donation is expected from the methoxy substituent, the shielding of the bridging acetate proton signals observed for complex 3 relative to the analogous protons in complex 2, suggests that mesomeric donation character is enhanced for the methoxy variant once coordinated to the respective rhodium atom in the bimetallic core. The counter ion acetate proton signals were observed to inversely mirror the trend in the bridging acetate signal, displaying a more shielded counter ion signal for the CF3 substituted complex (2). This observation was investigated by diffusion ordered spectroscopy (DOSY) to probe the interaction between the counter ion and axial coordination sites. For comparison, the DOSY spectra recorded for complexes 1 and 2 is shown in Figs. 2 and 3 respectively. The obtained DOSY spectra show a larger difference in the chemical shifts for the bridging and counter-ion acetate proton signals in complex 2 compared to the corresponding signal in complex 1. This suggests that the stronger the counter-ion to rhodium interaction in the complex is, the more significant the change in the observed diffusion of the counter ion acetate signal relative to the bridging acetate ligand signal. Therefore, in this series, the greater the de-shielding effects observed for acetate counter-ion proton signal, the higher the interaction between the metal atoms in the core of the complex and the counter ions. Consequently, this results in a larger observed separation between the chemical shift of the bridging acetate proton signals, relative to the counter ion proton signals in the DOSY spectrum. This infers the interaction between the acetate counter ion and the complex, observed as a 0.84 ppm and 1.5 ppm difference in the bridging and counter ion acetate signal for complexes 1 and 2 respectively. The 13C{1H}-NMR spectra collected for complexes 1 - 3 (Figs. S4-S6) display the expected number of signals, with C-F coupling observed for trifluoromethyl-bearing complex 2. The 19F NMR spectra recorded for complex 2 shows the expected signal resonating at 66.21 ppm (Fig. S7). Additionally, the obtained infrared spectral data supports successful synthesis in which a distinctive shift in the pyridyl CN absorption band is observed in the range from 1590 cm−1 to 1560 cm−1 upon binding to the respective rhodium ions (Fig. S8). The characteristic bands for the acetate moieties (CO and C-O modes) are observed in the 1400 cm−1 region. The high-resolution mass spectrometry (HRMS) data supports the formation of the target complexes with base peaks observed at m/z = 492.9715 and 378.0120 corresponding to an [M+DMSO-2OAc]2+ for complex 2 and [M-2OAc]2+ for complex 3 respectively, recorded in the positive ionization mode (Figs. S9, S10). To determine the counter ion effects on the axial site coordination and their influence on the electronic nature of the complexes, anion exchange reactions were carried out using complexes 1 - 3 following a reported procedure to afford complexes 4 - 6 bearing hexafluorophosphate (PF6 -) counter ions [53]. By way of example, the spectral comparison between complex 1 and 4 is shown in Fig. 4. The absence of the acetate proton signal in the 1.9 ppm region in the 1H NMR spectra recorded for complexes 4–6 suggests the successful exchange of the OAc- for the PF6 - anion (Figs. S11-S13). The absence of the counter ion acetyl signals in the 178–182 and 20–25 ppm regions of the 13C{1H}-NMR (Figs. S14-S16) as well as the presence of the signals in the respective 19F- and 31P{1H}-NMR spectra collected (Figs. S17-S18) further supports the successful ion exchange. The proton signal corresponding to the bridging acetate moiety was observed resonating at 2.48, 2.54 and 2.37 ppm for complexes 4, 5 and 6 respectively. Comparison of the bridging acetate signals show a minimal difference in the observed chemical shifts between trifluoromethyl-bearing complexes 2 and 5 where the DOSY analysis showed the largest diffusion coefficient difference, supporting the speculation of less prominent metal-to-counter ion interaction for complex 2. Conversely, a notable shift in the bridging acetate proton signals obtained for complexes 1 and 4 is observed from 2.56 to 2.48 ppm upon counter ion exchange and, coupled with the observed DOSY spectra further supports the proposed counter ion interaction. Comparison of the spectra collected for complexes 3 and 6 in DMSO show no difference in the bridging acetyl signal, due to the strong axial site binding capabilities of DMSO, displacing the axially bound acetate in the case of complex 3. Additionally, analysis of the collected infrared spectra for complexes 4 – 6 shows the expected absorption bands for the CN, CO and C-O groups in addition to a strong absorption band in the 800 cm−1 region, indicative of the P-F stretching mode corresponding to the counter-ion in each case (Fig. S19). The obtained HRMS spectra display base peaks corresponding to [M-2PF6]2+ ions at m/z = 317.9878, 453.9631 and 378.0121 for 4, 5 and 6 respectively (Figs. S20-S22). The purity of the newly synthesized hexafluorophosphate complexes was determined by high performance liquid chromatography (HPLC) where percentage purity of all synthesized complexes above 96 % was determined (Figs. S23-S25). 3.2 Electrochemical analysis of complexes with cyclic voltammetry Electrochemical analysis was carried out by cyclic voltammetry to determine the redox behavior of complexes 1 – 3, influenced by the electron-withdrawing or donating effects of the substituted bipyridyl ligands. The corresponding metal-centered 1-electron reduction potentials for the Rh2 4+ to Rh2 3+ event at − 0.91, − 0.85 and − 0.95 V are observed for complexes 1, 2 and 3 respectively ( Fig. 5). The obtained voltammograms show the expected trend in reduction potentials, with the trifluoromethyl substituted complex 2 presenting the lowest reduction potential. This can be attributed to the stabilizing effect emanating by strong inductive electron withdrawal of the CF3 group. The shoulder observed in the voltammogram obtained for complex 1 and the broad cathodic current observed in the reduction of complex 3 are ascribed to anion exchange of the acetate counter ion with the hexafluorophosphate present in the supporting electrolyte (TBAPF6) prepared. This was verified by comparison of the voltammograms obtained for complexes 1 and 4 (Fig. S26) with acetate and hexafluorophosphate anions respectively, whereby no significant shoulder is observed for hexafluorophosphate bearing complex 4. Additionally, this resulted in a corresponding cathodic shift in the reduction potential of approximately 50 mV upon hexafluorophosphate exchange, further supporting prominent axial interaction influence on the electronic nature occurring in complex 1. 3.3 Evaluation of axial interaction between OAc and PF6 containing complexes 1 and 4 The counter-ion interaction was further explored by monitoring the changes in the signals observed in 31P{1H} NMR, specifically the signal corresponding to triethylphosphine oxide (TEPO) when introduced to unsubstituted complexes containing acetate (complex 1) and hexafluorophosphate (complex 4) counter ions. Should the acetate axial site binding occur, coordination of the TEPO to the rhodium atoms would be hindered resulting in the same presentation of the TEPO phosphorous signal. The experiments were carried out by preparing solutions of complexes 1 and 4 with 1 equivalent of TEPO in MeOD at ambient temperature, in a similar manner as described for evaluation of the Lewis acidity measurements previously reported [54,55]. The spectrum obtained for complex 1 + TEPO shows no signal shift or change in splitting observed when compared to TEPO in MeOD (multiplet, 59.5 ppm), suggesting that no coordination of TEPO to the axial site of the complex has occurred (Fig. S27). This supports the speculated hemi-lability of the acetate binding to the axial sites of the dirhodium unit. A singlet (59.5 ppm) is observed in the spectrum obtained for complex 4 + TEPO with negligible shift as compared to TEPO in MeOH (Fig. S28). The observed splitting indicates an environment around the phosphorous atom which reduces the possible conformational arrangements in the ethyl chains of the TEPO molecule, implying coordination to the metal center in complex 4, where no acetate counter ion is present for competitive axial binding. Further insight into the axial site interaction of the hemi-labile counter ion was evaluated by measuring differences in the molar conductivity of acetate and hexafluorophosphate congeners of the unsubstituted (1 and 4) and trifluoromethyl substituted complexes (2 and 5), the results are presented in Table 1. The drastic increase in the recorded molar conductivity of complex 4 compared to 1 suggests axial binding of the acetate, thus affecting the ionic nature of the complex, supporting the observations in the DOSY and TEPO spectral analysis. Conversely, a negligible difference in the molar conductivity is observed for trifluoromethyl-substituted congeners, suggesting weak axial binding of the acetate counter ion, and supporting the larger difference in the signals observed in the DOSY spectrum obtained for complex 2. 3.4 Optimization of the conditions for the hydroformylation of 1-octene Following our previous findings for the homoleptic acetate complexes, the applicability of complexes 1 – 6 as catalyst precursors for the hydroformylation reaction was initiated by comparing the activity of complex 1 to the prototypical Rh2OAc4 complex investigated under the previously reported conditions (95 °C, 50 bar, 4 h) [51]. The data obtained shows comparable activity and chemoselectivity with minor favouring of branched over linear aldehyde products for complex 1 compared to Rh2OAc4, prompting further optimization of the hydroformylation conditions ( Table 2, entries 1 and 2) with complex 1. Temperature optimization was carried out at 55, 65, 75, 85 and 95 °C, with a maximum conversion of substrate observed from 85 °C (Table 2, entry 6). A significant decrease in conversion is observed between 75 and 85 °C, following a steady decline in conversion for reactions carried out lower temperatures (Table 2, entries 3–5). This indicates that the thermal requirements for the conversion of 1-octene substrate are satisfied from 85 °C. The observed plateau in conversion and production of aldehyde at this temperature indicates that the thermal requirements of the reaction are sufficient, leading to further optimization with syngas pressure and time being carried out at 85 °C. Pressure optimization was varied between 20 and 50 bar syngas (CO:H2, 1:1) where comparable conversion was achieved between 30 and 50 bar (Table 2, entries 6–8). A corresponding decrease in aldehyde production is observed with the change in gas pressure, decreasing from near quantitative yields (>96 %) of aldehyde between 50 and 40 bar (Table 2, entries 6 and 7), to 87 % and 61 % aldehyde yields produced at 30 and 20 bar respectively (Table 2, entries 8 and 9). Additionally, the observed regioselectivity (branched vs linear aldehyde) was found to be largely unaffected by changes in the gas pressure between 20 and 50 bar at 85 °C, resulting in observed n:iso ratios ranging between 0.69 and 0.78. This indicates low sensitivity regarding regioselectivity across this pressure range as observed for the fully substituted Rh2OAc4 complex [51]. The observed drop in aldehyde production from 30 bar suggests an optimized gas pressure of 40 bar be used for further optimization of the reaction conditions. Variation in the reaction time from 1 to 4 h at 85 °C and 40 bar syngas pressure for model complex 1 showed that near quantitative conversion of substrate is only attained after 3-hour reaction time (Table 2, entry 10), indicating a lower rate of substrate consumption for the dirhodium(II,II) N,N-chelate system compared to the fully substituted Rh2OAc4 previously reported [51]. This could be attributed to the electronic factors imparted by the chelating bipyridyl ligand or the binding acetate counter ion or the axial site occupancy factors of the hemi-labile counter ion competing with incoming substrate. The optimized conditions for further hydroformylation experiments were therefore determined to be 85 °C, 40 bar and 4 h. A mercury drop test was carried out to determine whether the observed hydroformylation activity is due to the formation of rhodium nanoparticles in combination with the molecular catalyst species (Table 2, entry 13) [48]. Comparison of the data obtained with and without the addition of mercury shows no significant reductions in the conversion or regioselectivity under these conditions. The chemoselectivity for aldehyde (97 %) in the presence of mercury suggests that the data obtained for hydroformylation is the result of a molecular species and not influenced by rhodium nanoparticle formation. 3.5 Bipyridyl co-ligand additive with Rh2OAc4 vs isolated complex 1: the effects on the hydroformylation of 1-octene under optimized conditions The use of co-ligands in catalytic reactions has shown to significantly influence reaction performance and product distributions, posing an interesting question of whether preforming complexes prior to catalytic evaluation is required [56]. To demonstrate the effects on the catalytic system with the isolated dirhodium(II,II) chelate complexes, a series of bipyridyl co-ligand experiments were carried out whereby the Rh2OAc4 complex was evaluated in the hydroformylation of 1-octene while varying equivalents of the 2,2′-bipyridyl as an additive ( Table 3, entries 1–3). The results indicate that although comparable conversion is achieved, higher chemoselectivity toward aldehyde is observed for the preformed complex 1 over the combination of Rh2OAc4 with 2 equivalents of bipyridyl ligand. Additionally, raising the relative amount of co-ligand to 4 equivalents yields a significant reduction in the conversion from 97 % to 47 %, likely due to competitive binding between substrate and co-ligand for available axial site coordination. The regioselectivity is greatly improved for linear aldehyde under these conditions, increasing from 44 % observed for complex 1 to 55 % and 71 % for co-ligand experiments with 2 and 4 equivalents respectively. This arises due to coordinative steric interactions of the Rh2OAc4 complex with excess bipyridyl ligand, a further consequence of the speculated coordination site competition between substrate and co-ligand additive. Raising the amount of co-ligand to 10 equivalents showed a further decrease in the conversion ability coupled with comparable chemoselectivity and regioselectivity for linear aldehyde (Table 3, entry 3). This substantiates the speculation of coordinative saturation of the complex, hindering substrate binding and thereby leading to a further decrease in the observed conversion. 3.6 Hydroformylation of 1-octene under optimized conditions Complexes 2–6 were evaluated in the hydroformylation of 1-octene under the optimized conditions of 85 °C, 40 bar and 4-hour reaction time, and the results compared to those obtained for complex 1. The results (Table S1) show comparable, near quantitative (>97 %) conversion of substrate across all tested complexes with no hydrogenation products (alcohols or alkanes) detected. Graphic representations depicting the chemo- and regioselectivities of the catalyst precursors are shown below in Figs. 6 and 7 respectively. Statistically comparable results for chemoselectivity for aldehyde are observed for complexes 1 and 2 at 96 % and 99 % respectively (Table S1, entries 1 and 2), with the methoxy substituted complex 3 (Table S1, entry 3) showing reduced aldehyde production at 84 %. This agrees with the recorded electrochemical data, whereby the lower reduction potential observed for complex 2 likely results in a faster reductive elimination step in the catalytic cycle. Similarly, the higher relative reduction potential for complex 3 causes slower reductive elimination and consequently forming the lowest amount of aldehyde between catalyst precursors 1 - 3. The proposed counter ion acetate interaction resulted in the highest regioselectivity toward linear aldehyde observed for complex 3, at 54 % (Table S1, entry 3), likely through increased steric interaction. Generally, the exchange of the counter ion from acetate to hexafluorophosphate significantly reduces reaction chemoselectivity for aldehyde. The largest notable reduction from 96 % to 83 % in the production of aldehyde is observed for complexes 1 and 4 bearing the unsubstituted bipyridyl ligand (Table S1, entries 1 and 4). This decrease in activity is attributed to the higher reduction potential observed for complex 4 relative to complex 1, resulting in a less stable Rh3+ species and hindering reductive elimination in the catalytic cycle (Fig S26). Furthermore, the absence of the counter ion acetate moiety generally results in a decrease in the regioselectivity toward linear aldehyde, suggesting that the increased steric control is likely through the acetate axial interaction. This is supported by the comparable regioselectivity observed between complexes 4 – 6 upon removal of the acetate counter ion. Similarly, the data obtained shows a reduction in aldehyde formation upon comparison of the acetate and hexafluorophosphate trifluoromethyl bearing complexes 2 and 5 (Table S1, entries 2 and 5). An increase in the chemoselectivity is observed between the methoxy congeners 3 and 6, (Table S1, entries 3 and 6) suggesting that a dominant axial interaction of the acetate-containing catalyst precursor may be further exploited for fine-tuning catalyst performance. Comparable chemoselectivity, regioselectivity and activity for trifluoromethyl and methoxy-substituted complexes with hexafluorophosphate counter-ions is observed (Table S1, entries 2 and 5), suggesting that the observed electronic effects of the bipyridyl ligand have a lower effect on the chemo- and regioselectivity of the hydroformylation reaction under these conditions. This supports the premise of a strong positive influence from the presence of the hemi-labile acetate counter-ion for outright aldehyde production, with the observed electronic effects between hexafluorophosphate analogues having little effect on the observed regioselectivity. The electrochemical characterization supports the hydroformylation data obtained for complexes 1–3 in increasing order of performance (activity) where complex 2 > complex 1 > complex 3, in agreement with the reductive potentials observed in the recorded voltammograms. However, the differences in the catalytic performance between hexafluorophosphate and acetate congeners does not account for the overall reduction in chemoselectivity toward aldehyde in all cases. Therefore, the combined data suggests that acetate counter ion involvement is necessary for maximized catalyst performance beyond initiation of the catalyst precursor and imparts some steric interaction to favor the formation of linear aldehydes. 3.7 Substrate scope (Styrene, 7-tetradecene, Cyclohexene) Extension of the substrate scope was carried out with the best performing pre-catalyst (complex 2) with respect to aldehyde production to determine any sensitivity of the catalyst system to long-chain internal aliphatic (7-tetradecene), benzylic (styrene) and cyclic (cyclohexene) olefins. Due to the higher energy requirements of long-chain internal olefins and the rigid-half-chair conformation of cyclohexene, these reactions were carried out at 105 °C [57,58]. The results for the reaction carried out with styrene substrate (Table 3, entry 4) shows near quantitative conversion (98 %) with 100 % chemoselectivity toward aldehyde since no isomerization of the substrate is possible. The regioselectivity toward branched aldehyde is a consequence of the anti-Markovnikov addition of the formyl group due to resonance stabilization at the benzylic position, culminating in the observed n:iso ratio of 0.75. Due to the respective molecular structures, linear aldehyde product was not observed for reactions carried out with 7-tetradecene and cyclohexene (Table 3, entries 5 and 6). The hydroformylation capabilities of complex 2 with 7-tetradecene as a substrate showed 76 % conversion, with 84 % total aldehyde production. The reaction carried out with cyclohexene resulted in a conversion percentage of 88 % and 100 % production of aldehyde as seen for the reaction with styrene substrate, albeit with only one aldehyde produced due to the nature of the cyclic olefin. The combined data suggests that the dirhodium(II,II) chelate complex containing the trifluoromethyl substituted bipyridyl ligand shows good to excellent substrate applicability, provided the energy requirements for the hydroformylation of the substrate are satisfied. 3.8 Recyclability of the catalyst precursor (6) By altering the properties of the bipyridyl substituent and anion, suitable temperature-dependent solubility of complex 6 was achieved toward catalyst recyclability in toluene, where maximal precipitation was observed after reactor cooling. Post-reaction catalyst precursor recycling was carried out by the application of steps from reported methods by cooling the post-catalytic reaction mixture to 0 °C overnight, following the formation of a green precipitate [27,30]. The supernatant was decanted, and the precipitate was washed with cold toluene in 3 cycles, before reintroduction to the respective reactor with fresh internal standard, substrate, and solvent. The results (Table S1, entries 7–11) show good activity over 5 cycles, maintaining TOF values of above 500 h-1 introducing a facet of catalytic precursor recyclability to the dirhodium(II,II) catalysed homogeneous hydroformylation reaction ( Fig. 8). The data obtained shows a negligible decrease in activity and is attributed to minor catalyst precursor loss in the collection and washing steps between cycles affecting the error in the data obtained for each cycle. Negligible differences in the chemoselectivity for aldehyde are observed upon recycling with comparable regioselectivities (49–53 % linear aldehyde) observed between the first and fifth cycle (Table 3, entries 7 and 11). After 5 cycles, the recovered solid was analysed by 1H NMR spectroscopy ( Fig. 9). The spectroscopic data display the expected proton signals corresponding to the precursor complex 6 seen prior to the catalytic reaction. This indicates that post-catalytic regeneration of the catalyst precursor is observed without degradation or poisoning occurring over 5 cycles. 4 Conclusions In conclusion, three dirhodium(II,II) acetato-bipyridyl complexes with acetate counter ions, and three hexafluorophosphate analogues were synthesized in moderate to excellent yields (68–96 %). A direct relation between differences in chemical shift of the counter ion and the bridging acetate proton signal was observed in the DOSY spectra, suggesting differences in axial site affinity of the acetate counter ion. The evaluation of the redox behavior by cyclic voltammetry revealed that the electron-withdrawing trifluoromethyl complex 2 showed the lowest reduction potential relative to the unsubstituted complex 1. Hexafluorophosphate analogues (4 - 6) were synthesized for comparison of the electronic and spectral data and applicability in the hydroformylation reaction. The title complexes were evaluated as catalyst precursors in the hydroformylation of 1-octene, showing comparable performance under milder conditions compared to the previously reported dirhodium(II,II) tetraacetate. The observed effect on conversion, chemo- and regioselectivity were attributed to the increased steric interactions at higher ligand concentrations. The observed trends in chemoselectivity for complexes containing acetate counter ions were ascribed to the redox characteristics for complexes 1 – 3. Additionally, strong dependence of the regioselectivity and axial interaction of the acetate counter ion was observed with complex 3, presenting the highest production of linear aldehyde due to steric influence. The best performing catalyst precursor (2) was applied toward substrate scope evaluation in the hydroformylation of styrene, 7-tetradecene and cyclohexene with good conversion and production of aldehyde. Suitable solubility characteristics were observed for complex 6, allowing for the prospect of catalyst precursor recyclability. Post-catalytic precipitation at low temperature was achieved in aid of catalyst recyclability. Negligible differences in activity and selectivity were observed, with analysis of the recovered solid showing no degradation of the catalyst precursor after recycling. coredata.dc:description: The synthesis of cationic bimetallic ‘pseudo-paddlewheel’ dirhodium(II,II) acetato-bipyridyl complexes of the type [Rh2(OAc)2(bis-4,4′-R-bipy)2]2+ containing either acetate (AcO-) or hexafluorophosphate (PF 6 - ) counter ions is described. In both series, the 4 and 4′ positions of each bipyridyl ligand are substituted such that R = H, CF3 or OMe (complexes 1-3 for AcO- and 4-6 for PF6 - derivatives). As catalyst precursors for the hydroformylation reaction, the complexes were initially evaluated using 1-octene as a substrate. The complex which displayed the greatest chemoselectivity toward aldehydes was evaluated further as a catalyst precursor for the hydroformylation of styrene, cyclohexene and 7-tetradecene as substrates. A correlation between product distributions in terms of chemo- and regioselectivity in the hydroformylation reaction versus axial site interaction is delineated. Recyclability was achieved through suitable modification of the substituent and counter ion, culminating in a simplistic method of post-catalytic precursor collection with minimal reduction of the catalytic activity over 5 cycles.
